Mr stewart, have you had previous judicial experience?

ID: 1047299638937538680

Not to mention my extensive public service career in which I have seen the ins and outs of both the Executive and Legislative branches, on both the federal and state levels.
ID: 1047299878633603113
Deleted User
11:57 PM

ID: 1047300334957109318
Justice Chuck Stewart
12:01 AM
@Deleted User
I see, how many cases have you tried in your tenure as a magistrate judge. If you do not remember, a
Unfortunately, due to the lack of cases being filed in the system (only two have been filed during my entire tenure), and due to the fact of the stubborn attitudes of some litigators, I have not been able to preside over any cases. However, I would like to thank my colleague, Judge Bolton, for attempting to refer multiple cases, only to be denied by litigators for small reasons. But, I have learned a great deal in the position about the judicial branch which will help me greatly if I am to be confirmed.

derek | „Éá„É¨„ÉÉ„ÇØ FREE ALDERAAN
09:17 PM
What's your favourite part of the constitution
ID: 1047622444732665969
derek | „Éá„É¨„ÉÉ„ÇØ FREE ALDERAAN
09:17 PM
How much would you respect precedent in your rulings
ID: 1047622503431946240
Justice Chuck Stewart
10:59 PM
@derek | „Éá„É¨„ÉÉ„ÇØ FREE ALDERAAN
What's your favourite part of the constitution
I would have to say the first amendment. It enshrines our key freedoms (speech, religion, press, assembly, and to petition the government), and our society most definitely would not be the same without it. However, I believe that the Constitution as a whole is a strong document that should always be respected.
ID: 1047648209843011604
Justice Chuck Stewart
11:04 PM
@derek | „Éá„É¨„ÉÉ„ÇØ FREE ALDERAAN
How much would you respect precedent in your rulings
As tradition dictates, in general I would be cautious to overturn a longstanding precedent for no reason, as doing so completely disregards the fact that the decision has been the law of the land for many years. However, if there was a precedent that was clearly incorrectly decided, or if there is a new view of that precedent revealed, I would not shy away from overturning precedent if necessary.
ID: 1047649334705012816

ID: 1051317986457292922
Deleted User
02:02 AM
@Justice Chuck Stewart What is your thoughts on legislating from the bench
ID: 1051318038298902548
Justice Chuck Stewart
02:08 AM
@Deleted User
<@586551302977486861> What is your thoughts on legislating from the bench
I believe that judicial activism (also known as legislating from the bench) is a wholly unacceptable way of delivering justice and making rulings in cases. A large point of the judiciary in this country is to act as a check on Congress, so that after a law is made it can be properly scrutinized to ensure its constitutionality. Although one could consider striking down a law "legislating," it has been within the scope of the court for over two hundred years, with the concept of judicial review first being affirmed in *Marbury* (5 U.S. 137). Judicial activists on the bench often claim that the constitution or other legal documents provide for certain concepts as a partisan measure, and do not look at these documents with an unbiased eye in the scope of the case which is being determined. I do believe that when required, however, a judge should not be afraid to overturn incorrect precedent over fears of being called a judicial activist, as if a judge is truly doing justice, then in some cases precedent must be overturned.
ID: 1051319427049734204
Deleted User
02:08 AM
Thank you
ID: 1051319561418461184
Deleted User
02:09 AM
@Justice Chuck Stewart
I believe that judicial activism (also known as legislating from the bench) is a wholly unacceptable
Do you believe that a "superprecedent" exists?
ID: 1051319666892607590
Justice Chuck Stewart
02:15 AM
@Deleted User
Do you believe that a "superprecedent" exists?
Yes, I do believe that in cases that have been foundational to our system of government, one could consider a "super-precedent" to exist, essentially requiring very solid and necessary reasoning for overturning the case. For example, not to sound like a broken record, but *Marbury* is one of the most foundational precedents and decisions to our system of government in this country, and I think that unless serious new facts or perspective emerge that require the overruling of the case, it would be a mistake to throw away two hundred years of legal theory. I also believe that precedents that dictate the key rights of some citizens in this country, such as *Brown* (347 U.S. 483) should not be overturned without an extremely compelling and necessary reasoning, which I believe is unlikely to happen considering that the overturning of the case would cause for the reduction of rights of over 40% of the population.
ID: 1051321292017635378
Deleted User
02:16 AM
@Justice Chuck Stewart
Yes, I do believe that in cases that have been foundational to our system of government, one could c
what cases do you believe are "superprecedents? Alongside Marbury v Madison and Brown v Board of Education"
ID: 1051321581558829167
Justice Chuck Stewart
02:38 AM (edited)
@Deleted User
what cases do you believe are "superprecedents? Alongside Marbury v Madison and Brown v Board of Edu
In the same vain as *Brown*, I would have to note the cases *Smith v. Allwright* (321 U.S. 649) and *Shelly v. Kraemer* (334 U.S. 1) due to their significance of protecting the rights of minorities in this countries.
ID: 1051327021554356334

ID: 1073300542534721580
Vice-President Noah (L-AR-JK)
07:24 PM
Thank you for your time, sir, and apologies on the delay in questioning.
I was asked by a colleague to ask the following questions, and may have additional questions of my own at a later time. For now though, here are my questions.

What mode of constitutional interpretation do you subscribe to?

Do you believe that gerrymandering is subject to judicial review?

How much should the court rely on severing? Should that be left to the legislature?

Do you support the concept of substantive due process?

Do you support the enforcement of the dormant commerce clause?

What is your view on compelled speech? Should it how used to rectify discrimination by businesses?

Should the Safe Harbor Doctrine apply to website hosting businesses?

What is your opinion on the Chevron Doctrine?

The Takings Clause of the 5th Amendment states, "just compensation" be paid if private property is taken for public use. What does public use mean to you? Accessible by the public, or simply benefiting the public, or something else.

What is the most important aspect of our Constitution?

If someone was not in this hearing and looked through it to decide their vote, what would you want them to take away from it?

Would you be able to decide a case that goes against your moral beliefs?
ID: 1073323570295488684
Meir Yaari revived(Do not Whip)
09:27 AM
Apologies for not answering yet(sorry, I stopped checking cause no one asked and wasnt pinged), I hope I will be allowed to answer these questions now
ID: 1073535559810678824
Meir Yaari revived(Do not Whip)
09:59 AM
@Vice-President Noah (L-AR-JK)
Thank you for your time, sir, and apologies on the delay in questioning. I was asked by a colleague
1. I consider myself an originalist, in the sense of original public meaning- It is my belief that the best way we have to understand a law is by how the puublic understood it at the time, and thus, what, as the sovereign, the public intended as law. I also have great respect for precedent, however.
2. Yes. Within a reasonable basis. There is no constitutional or legal basis for the review of *partisan* gerrymandering, However, under the equal protection clause and the fifteenth amendment there is clearly a protection for racial voting, as seen by the strong protections given to the right of voting during the time of reconstruction, when these amendments were put in place.
3. If the legislature provides severability, the court must respect that. If however, it does not, it is up to the court, using reasonability and precedent, to decide whether to sever or not.
4. I think that it is clear, as explained by justice Miller, that a view that needlessly limits due process to former slaves is one that makes the amendment thoroughly moot, and as such doesnt stand to scrutiny. Furthermore, this was clearly upholded in *Griswold*. That being said, I would warn against overexpansion of due process such as in the *Pierce* case.
5. In Federalist#11 Alexander Hamilton makes it clear that uniform trade amongst the states is a clear aim of the federalist project, and without it, the union will be weak. This is an important part of the compromises that made the constitution possible. The main aim of the dormant commerce clause is to maintain this- as such, I support its enforcement, as the enforcement of an important aspect of our constitution.
6. Compelled speech is clearly unconstitutional under the first amendment. That being said, we must measure certain rights against others. Commercial Speech, as I believe you are referring to with the question on discrimination, has weaker protections than individual speech, as can be seen with the 'Zauderer standard'...
ID: 1073543684869595177
Meir Yaari revived(Do not Whip)
10:16 AM (edited)
which unanimously established that as commercial entities are not individuals, their speech is only protected in that it gives value to consumers.
7. Certaintly. I would add that O.P.A.S. Act has significantly changed privacy protections given, so that should be taken in account.
8.It is very important for the court not to 'legislate from the bench' as it were. *Chevron* is very important in the prevention of that, and I support it.
9. It is very clear(as can be seen in the path to its legislation, and in other parts of it), that the intent of the bill of rights was to protect citizens from an overzealous government. If so, the idea that it was the intention or understanding of the takings clause to allow an overzealous government to take property for any reasons is absurd on its face. I highly reject *Kelo* and its like.
10. The protection of the citizen from the government.
11. I wouldnt want to tell anyone how to vote- they may look at my qualifications and doctrine and decide for themselves.
12. Yes, the constitution is more important than my moral beliefs.
ID: 1073547907594211358
Meir Yaari revived(Do not Whip)
10:16 AM
Is that all @Vice-President Noah (L-AR-JK) ?
ID: 1073547997138395187

ID: 1075524012664422480
Justice Anthony Bolton
09:10 PM

ID: 1075524590115237918
Justice Anthony Bolton
09:17 PM
As with my first hearing to be a federal judge I shall state my qualifications

I have a bachelors degree in Liberal Arts specifically a major in political science at the University of Texas at Austin. I have a doctorate in law from Texas Tech University. I was an attorney in both civil and criminal cases in the State of Texas and was formerly barred in the State of Texas. As you may already know I am a former judge of the District Court I have been nominated to. After resigning from the Judgeship, I pursued certification in the Superior Court of Olympia and passed my bar exam shortly before being recess appointed by the President. I am barred in both Lincoln and Olympia however I am no longer barred Frontier as they released a new exam, while I was serving on the bench, and required that everyone requalify.

Now some of you may ask as to why I have been nominated to return to the bench so soon after resigning and it is because I noticed while serving in the House of Representatives, that the President had yet to fill the vacancies on the court. Access to Justice is important to me and I filed my application for Federal Judgeship as well as contacted the President on whether he had any nominations. His team vetted me and decided that I qualified to return to the court.
I am happy to receive any questions you may have.
ID: 1075526320592797797
Speaker Brown (the hot one)
09:21 PM
Thank you Mr. Bolton
ID: 1075527411048906792
Speaker Brown (the hot one)
09:22 PM
I have a few questions I would like you to ask at your leisure
ID: 1075527482201092226
Speaker Brown (the hot one)
09:22 PM
Do you believe Janus was correctly decided?
What should be the burden for overturning precedent? How much do you believe in stare decisis?
What level of scrutiny do you believe should be applied to gun rights?
Do you believe the court was correct to curtail the Sherbert test?
Are you in favor or against commandeering (relating to states and the federal government (not property))?
Do you believe the Lemon test is a good precedent or should it be done away with?
Should the Political Question Doctrine be re-evaluated?
If a court decision is to be overturned, should it be done so gradually or swiftly?
ID: 1075527542133493790
Mr. Deb
02:11 AM
Mr. Chairman, the Minority Leader has assigned Senator Cryptic and myself to this committee. @Speaker Brown (the hot one)
ID: 1075600250229751889
Justice Anthony Bolton
02:42 AM
@Speaker Brown (the hot one)
Do you believe Janus was correctly decided? What should be the burden for overturning precedent? How
On the first question I agree in part with the Majority Opinion of the court in that non-consenting public employees should not be required to pay union fees even if they benefit from the Unions themselves but the Court should have also taken into consideration the consequences of the decision that would affect over 20 states at the time, as Justice Kagan had said in the dissenting opinion.

The Supreme Court has often states that the burden for overturning precedent "must be based on some special justification or, at least 'strong grounds' that extends beyond the Court's mere disagreement with the merits of the prior decision's reasoning" but the Court has created exceptions if it finds a case to be "poorly reasoned [or] lacked workability" as stated in Janus v. AFSCME. Stare decisis is important and as a District Judge precedent of higher courts is binding on my consideration of any case.

As a consideration that the right to bear arms is a constitutional right provided by the 2nd Amendment as of current gun rights and laws are subject to strict scrutiny but the Supreme Court has provided outer limits under D.C. v. Heller and McDonald v. Chicago. That is what level of scrutiny I will apply.

I don't believe it to be in my authority to decide whether or not the court was correct to curtail the Sherbert test. Regardless of what I think I would be bound by it. However I note that Freedom of Religion is not absolute and the government does have the authority to regulate conduct if it is for a secular purpose and not with the intent to inhibit religion, which is part of the Lemon Test.
ID: 1075608059088470117
Justice Anthony Bolton
02:42 AM
The Constitution provides that government has the power of eminent domain and may exercise this power if they provide just compensation. Commandeering is an action of officially taking possession or control of something especially for military purposes. The military is under the authority of the government and therefore must abide by the constitution, when commandeering. There is no favorability that I can take in this question.

The Lemon test has three prongs, did the government make the law or action in question for a secular purpose, does it advance or inhibit religion, and does it result in excessive entanglements between the state and religion. The test has some usefulness for the court but it is also worth looking at precedent previously established when determining when something may violate the establishment clause or the free exercise clause.

The intent of the Political Question Doctrine is to maintain the separation of powers between the Judiciary and the other branches. Federal courts in a sense adjudicate on "political" questions quite frequently when it comes to controversial and government-related issues. The term "political question" often expresses that some issues are left solely to another branch of government. The simplest example would be the Rules of Congress which we cannot adjudicate which is indeed protected under the constitution.

Determining when and how a court's decision should be overturned would not be within my power unless such precedent that was established were at my level and no further. However if it was within my power it would have to depend on the circumstances of the case before me. Some decisions may be easy to overturn, others may not and warrant a gradual change.
ID: 1075608098007425095
Speaker Brown (the hot one)
04:25 AM

Mr. Chairman, the Minority Leader has assigned Senator Cryptic and myself to this committee. <@99873

Mr. Deb
04:34 AM (edited)
Mr. Bolton, I have a few questions.

Do you believe that in the decision in *Shelby County V. Holder* the Supreme Court was right to strike down provisions in the Voting Rights Act of 1965 relating to the formula used to determine which jurisdictions are subject to the preclearance requirement?

What is your decision making process look like when you approach cases. More specifically, how do you approach the application of precedent and the necessary overturning of such.

What do you think the limits are to the 8th Amendment's prohibition against "Cruel and Unusual Punishments". Do you tend to agree with previous court precedents?

@Justice Anthony Bolton
ID: 1075636207742107648
Speaker Brown (the hot one)
06:10 PM
@Justice Anthony Bolton I just have some final questions that I would love to hear your answer on.

What is your stance on Ricca v. U.S.?

What is your stance on Regents of the University of California v. Bakke?

What is your stance on Planned Parenthood v. Casey?

What is your stance on Whole Woman‚Äôs Health v. Hellerstedt?

What is your stance on D.C. v. Heller?
ID: 1075841493912256522
Speaker Brown (the hot one)
06:10 PM
after all the questions have been answered the hearing shall conclude and we'll bring it back to the committee for action.
ID: 1075841686493745234
Justice Anthony Bolton
08:13 PM
@Mr. Deb
Mr. Bolton, I have a few questions. Do you believe that in the decision in *Shelby County V. Holder
My stance on Shelby is complicated. On one hand I agree with Justice Ginsburg's dissent in that Congress had the power to enforce that action through the 14th and 15th amendment and that Congress "must show that the means taken rationally advance a legitimate objective". On the other I also agree with then Chief Justice Roberts' opinion that formula was outdated and no longer reflected the changes that have occurred and now represented an unconstitutional violation of the power to regulate election.

When I consider a case before me I first consider the circumstances of the case, the question(s) before the court and carefully and impartially examine the text of the law and the constitution and the author's intent in conjunction with relevant precedent and precedent that the parties have presented in their arguments. I have stated previously I would not have the authority to overturn precedent unless it has been created at a level which I can reject that precedent. When overturning precedent I would apply what the Supreme Court determines to be the burden for overturning precedent which I stated in my second answer to the Senior Senator for Frontier.

The Supreme Court has create an evolving standards test in which the Court should apply the public opinion of the punishment in question as well as looking to states' legislatures and the juries. That is how I would determine the limits and it would have to be on a case by case basis in which I would apply that test and review any precedent on the 8th Amendment's application.
ID: 1075872588011667599
Justice Anthony Bolton
08:54 PM
@Speaker Brown (the hot one)
<@678752937589080065> I just have some final questions that I would love to hear your answer on. Wh
I cannot take a stance on *Ricca v. U.S.* as I was unable to find any opinion on the case other than the Supreme Court opinion which simply states the Supreme Court upholds the District Court's ruling. In essence I am not familiar with the case as I do not know of the District Court's ruling.

*Regents of the University of California v. Bakke* is complicated as there was no majority opinion but a plurality opinion. I agree with both opinions filed in that a rigid racial quota is in violation of the equal protections clause and I also agree with the other opinion that the use of race was permissible as a criterion in order to provide for equity in education.

*Planned Parenthood v. Casey* reaffirmed Roe and additionally provided a standard that the lower courts should take into account when determining the validity of abortion laws. The standard asks whether the regulation(s) "has purpose or effect of imposing an undue burden" the court provides that an undue burden is defined as "a substantial obstacle in the path of a woman seeking an abortion before the fetus attains viability." I believe this case provided a useful tool for lower courts to determine if abortion laws are constitutional or not under *Roe v. Wade*.

*Whole Woman's Health v. Hellerstedt* reaffirmed Roe and Casey and I agree in part with the decision as it applied the standard created under *Planned Parenthood v. Casey*

I agree in part with *D.C. v. Heller* in that a ban on registering handguns, and that owners keep registered firearms unloaded and disassembled were unconstitutional. However I also agree with Justice Stevens dissent that the second amendment does not create an unlimited right to possess guns for self-defense and that the legislature does have some power to regulate non-military use and ownership of weapons.
ID: 1075882840262201354
Justice Anthony Bolton
08:55 PM
Thank you all for having me here.
*packs up and leaves*

ID: 1078397643325177947
Meir Yaari revived(Do not Whip)
07:31 PM
I understand that my renomination is something that is unique, and I do not belive my passage is something that should be guaranteed, or freely given. The renomination was done with the joint understanding of the president and I that the nomination was not given sufficient consideration, and the belief that such consideration is appropriate. Given that, ask away! If there is something that you wish to consider in your voting, ask me about it, I cannot guarantee I will give you the answer you desire, but I can guarentee honesty. If there is a response that is unclear or requires elaboration, once again, please ask me. With that aside,

I believe I am fit for this role given my past in service to this country, legal and in the offices of congress and the presidency. I am not beholden to any political interest, and am a firm believer in the constitution above any doctrine, but with that said, I consider myself an originalist, and a firm believer in the original public meaning. If that is something you wish to keep in mind, so be it, but be aware that my firm belief in precedent and the particularities of cases mean I will not always align with the 'orthodoxy' on originalism. I am ready for questioning!

@Meir Yaari revived(Do not Whip)
I understand that my renomination is something that is unique, and I do not belive my passage is som
Mr. Notmoonguy I have a few questions I'd like you to answer.
Do you believe Janus was correctly decided?
What should be the burden for overturning precedent? How much do you believe in stare decisis?
What level of scrutiny do you believe should be applied to gun rights?
Do you believe the court was correct to curtail the Sherbert test?
Are you in favor or against commandeering (relating to states and the federal government (not property))?

ID: 1078440260071080037
Meir Yaari revived(Do not Whip)
02:43 PM
@Speaker Brown (the hot one)
Mr. Notmoonguy I have a few questions I'd like you to answer. Do you believe Janus was correctly dec
1. I do not think it is. For example, one could consider the forms of collective speech that we as a country have been practicing since the time of the founding fathers, for example organizational speech or government speech. Such speech is not always approved of by the members, and doesnt always represent the members, but the members agree to it via contract. There does not seem to be much precedent to suggest the interpretation of free speech by the court in Janus.
2. Stare decisis is something I deeply care about, and the burden for overturning precedent should be strong. Of course, it should be capable, there have been some decisions that were poorly reasoned or poorly decided, but the case for that must be very strongly made. As for gun rights, I believe the precedent for the second amendment has been fairly permissive, especially in the aftermath of the Heller case, and I will stick to this precedent when trying to scrutinize restrictions on second amendment rights.
3. As for the curtailing of the Sherbert test, are you referring to the decision made in *Employment division v Smith*? Because the sherbert test has since been legislated.
4. I disagree with a strict Anti-Commandeering doctrine, forged from the aftermath of the *Prinz* case, which I believe is ahistorical(see https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=2012744) that being said, the precedent regarding commandeering is strong, and I will respect that, and the Anti-Commandeering doctrine which guides it, when making decisions if I am confirmed.
ID: 1078688708162760784
Meir Yaari revived(Do not Whip)
02:48 PM
5. I think, as Justice Scalia noted several times, the Lemon test is problematic in its applications. That being said, I do still believe that is fundamentally a good framework to discuss violations of the establishment clause through, through its separation of violations into prongs that can be individually discussed as part of a whole. I would look at precedent regarding establishment clause violations rather than the wanton usage of the Lemon test though, as they often conflict, as Scalia noted.
6. No, I highly disagree with this. The Political Question doctrine lies in the heart of what seperates the Judicial Branch from the Legislative or Executive Branch- not everything is Justiciable. Some questions were intended by the framers of the constitution to be answered by the respective branches, and the court must, as with all constitutional cases, interpret these restrictions in a way that maximizes the protections of individual rights created by the constitution, and the democratic decision-making process.
7. This is a question that strongly hinges on how old the precedent is, and how much precedent depends on it. For example, if we were to overturn a case like *Marbury*, I'd say that it would require a slow and careful intepretation! However, a case like Plessy v Ferguson or Korematsu, should they have still been in effect, should be overturned with haste.
ID: 1078690006987702442
Speaker Brown (the hot one)
04:14 PM
@Meir Yaari revived(Do not Whip)
5. I think, as Justice Scalia noted several times, the Lemon test is problematic in its applications
Just have some last questions for you Mr. Notmoonguy, thank you for taking the time to answer my questions.
What is your stance on Roe v. Wade?
What is your stance on the 2nd Amendment?
Do you believe there should be restrictions on purchasing firearms?
Do you believe Associate Justices should have the right to affiliate with a Party? If not, why?
What is your favorite SCOTUS ruling and why?
Why do you think you should be confirmed to the Court?
ID: 1078711588481155192
Meir Yaari revived(Do not Whip)
07:08 PM
@Speaker Brown (the hot one)
Just have some last questions for you Mr. Notmoonguy, thank you for taking the time to answer my que
1. I believe that Roe V Wade is firm precedent, and one I will uphold as a District Judge so long as the congress does not make any law reversing it, especially in the aftermath of the *Casey* and recent *Carter* case. Whilst there is a case towards revisiting *Roe* perhaps, as district judge it will not be within my purview to challange it.
2. Like I said, in likght of decisions such as D.C. vs Heller as well as the *Mcdonald* case, it is clear that the court has taken a very liberal attitude regarding the scope of second amendment rights, and I will make decisions in light of that, whillst also keeping the specific writings of the framers and the context for the formation of the second amendment in mind.
3. My opnion on if there *should* be restrictions on firearms is irrelevant. What I believe you might be asking is if I believe that there are restrictions on the purchase of firearms that are constitutional. If that is the case, the answer is yes. There have always been regulations on the purchase of firearms, whilst making clear that the second amendment is sacrosanct.
4. Yes, Associate Justices should be allowed to affiliate with a party within the limits of free speech, even though in my opinion, they *should not*.
5. Wow, hard to say. In terms of effects, I guess I would say *Brown v Board*. In term of my liking of the opinion on a technical level? I queite like scalias dissent in *Hamdi v Rumsefeld*
6. As I said, I have a long history within every level of the legal discipline, and I believe I could serve the court well.

First item from the Senate is S.2 ( https://docs.google.com/document/d/1tZBNZkJlWdIvhB5-K1w1OGHn5d6uBp5b6--MCXdq084/edit?usp=sharing) debate shall be open until a motion of recommendation to the Senate is made.
S.2 "Secure Online Communications and Child Protection Act"
IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES May 16th, 2023 Mr. Brown (for himself,) introduced the following bill; A BILL Creates a commission to develop recommended best practices for providers of interactive computer services to prevent, reduce, and respond to online child sexual exploitati...
ID: 1109222770514083920
Speaker Brown (the hot one)
09:06 PM
as this is my bill I will take a moment to give a small explanation of what it does.
ID: 1109225575983349760
Speaker Brown (the hot one)
09:07 PM
now this is a really long piece of legislation, 33 pages and it makes a lot of technical changes to code concerning prosecution of online sexual exploitation.
ID: 1109225959682490418
Speaker Brown (the hot one)
09:08 PM
This bill also establishes a commission to head off this problem and prevent it from happening.
ID: 1109226109276541070
Speaker Brown (the hot one)
09:09 PM
much like my other bill about social media it hold the companies accountable for any sexual exploitation happening on their site.
ID: 1109226263341711429
Speaker Brown (the hot one)
09:10 PM (edited)
this bill will also head off the serious problem of child pornography we have in this country.
ID: 1109226599544541184
Speaker Brown (the hot one)
09:11 PM (edited)
I have a small list that my assistant came up with that I will pass around for everyone.
*reads the paper*
"1. Create an expert Commission composed of representatives from government agencies, law enforcement, prosecutors, academia, survivors/nonprofits, and technology companies. The Commission will compile advisory best practices relating to preventing, reducing, and responding to online child sexual exploitation. Best practices will be voluntary, not mandatory or binding, and will serve to guide companies that wish to implement measures to protect children from sexual exploitation online.
2. Amend the Communications Decency Act to enable interactive service providers to be subject to Federal and State civil liability and State criminal liability under child pornography laws.
3. Replace ‚Äúchild pornography‚Äù with ‚Äúchild sexual abuse material‚Äù throughout the U.S. criminal code.
4. Enhance the NCMEC CyberTipline to require reporting of child sex trafficking and online enticement, streamline reporting, and enable information-sharing to respond to child sexual abuse material.
5. Allow a court to consider evidence of actions or circumstances relating to materials involving the sexual exploitation of minors if the evidence is otherwise admissible.
6. Provide that actions or services involving encrypted messaging services shall not serve as an independent basis for liability of interactive service providers for a claim or charge relating to child sexual abuse material."
ID: 1109226925710389338
Speaker Brown (the hot one)
09:12 PM
I hopes that helps you further understand my bill and I hope you will vote it for Senate consideration. With that I yield for any questions you may have.

S. 5, "Illegal Gun Registry Prevention Act"
165TH CONGRESS 1ST SESSION S. 5 To require the destruction of certain records and prevent the formation of a de-facto gun registry. IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES MAY 21, 2023 Mr. NOAH (for himself and Mr. GUY) introduced the following bill; A BILL To require the destruction of cer...

ID: 1110379037228027914
Speaker Brown (the hot one)
02:32 AM
Debate is open on S.5, @Vice-President Noah (L-AR-JK) is invited to the Judiciary committee to give a presentation and answer any questions the committee may have,
ID: 1110394723622998106
Speaker Brown (the hot one)
02:39 AM
the committee shall remain unmoderated subject to call of the chair. <:HammerTime:712031635331219586> @Senate Judiciary Committee
ID: 1110396507938631730
Vice-President Noah (L-AR-JK)
08:13 PM (edited)
Thank you, Mr Chairman and members of the committee. Essentially, when a gun store (FFL) goes out of business, the ATF currently takes all the copies of their Form 4473s, which you can think of as a detailed gun receipt. Despite it being illegal by the Firearm Owner's Protection Act, the ATF has compiled records into a massive searchable database of every gun owner whose gun store happened to go out of business.
To ease some fears about this bill, there are 5 ways the ATF will keep a record on a gun.
> Multiple Sale Reports, where someone purchases multiple handguns in a short time period.
> Suspect guns, which are guns that are suspected of criminal use, and may or may not be in law enforcement's possession.
> Traced guns, which are when guns are subject to a trace request.
> Theft guns, which are guns reported as stolen.
> And, finally, out of business records, where the original FFL goes out of business. You'll notice this is the only indiscriminate massive record-keeping operation.
ID: 1110661731396628601
Vice-President Noah (L-AR-JK)
08:15 PM
I only want to eliminate one of the 5. The only indiscriminate, unnecessary, unwarranted, and unaccountable list. This has formed a *de facto* gun registry for all guns sold at stores that have gone out of business, and said registry is illegal by the Firearm Owner's Protection Act.
> No such rule or regulation prescribed [by the Attorney General] after the date of the enactment of the Firearms Owners Protection Act may require that records required to be maintained under this chapter or any portion of the contents of such records, be recorded at or transferred to a facility owned, managed, or controlled by the United States or any State or any political subdivision thereof, nor that any system of registration of firearms, firearms owners, or firearms transactions or disposition be established. Nothing in this section expands or restricts the Secretary's authority to inquire into the disposition of any firearm in the course of a criminal investigation.
ID: 1110662323477164093
Vice-President Noah (L-AR-JK)
08:16 PM
Senators, Mr Chairman, I welcome your questions, and urge your yes vote on this bill.
ID: 1110662489139585175
Speaker Brown (the hot one)
08:53 PM (edited)
Thank you Senator Noah, does the have any questions? @Senate Judiciary Committee

09:34 PM

Sabastien Charest-Harris; on behalf of the Department of Justice.
ID: 1111028406650413177
Speaker Brown (the hot one)
08:30 PM
thank you, go ahead.
ID: 1111028443291865192
Deleted User
08:42 PM
Chairman, Ranking Member, and distinguished Members of the Senate Judiciary Committee, thank you for providing me with the opportunity to express my support for S.5, the *Illegal Gun Registry Prevention Act.* I believe this legislation addresses a matter of utmost importance, namely the delicate balance between the rights of individuals and the duty of the federal government to maintain public safety.

The *Illegal Gun Registry Prevention Act*, as its name suggests, mandates the destruction of certain firearms transaction records currently held by my office, and prevents the collection of similar records in the future unless a court warrant authorizes it. This measure is designed to alleviate the valid concerns of American citizens who fear the creation of a de facto gun registry.

As Attorney General, I am tasked with ensuring that the rights of American citizens are upheld, and that includes the Second Amendment. This bill strengthens our commitment to that obligation by ensuring that the privacy of law-abiding gun owners is not infringed upon, thus respecting their constitutional right to bear arms. That being said, the bill also recognizes the necessity of the federal government to have access to certain records when they are deemed relevant to a legal investigation. The requirement for a warrant to compile a list of legal gun owners ensures that there are proper checks and balances in place, respecting the Fourth Amendment rights of individuals against unreasonable searches and seizures.

Furthermore, by putting the onus of record-keeping on businesses and individuals, S.5 moves us away from the practice of the federal government collecting large amounts of data about law-abiding citizens. It aligns with the principle of limited government, ensuring that we are not unnecessarily intruding into the private lives of American citizens. When needed, however, the government can still access these records through the established legal procedure of obtaining a court-authorized warrant. I would like to highlight the reporting provision of the Act, which mandates the Attorney General to report to Congress the number of firearm transaction records destroyed pursuant to this Act. This serves as an accountability measure, ensuring that the provisions of the Act are being followed.

If passed, I shall expressly abide by this express Congressional measure; my office is in-fact compiling the necessary data in order to get this done upon signature of the President.

I remember when the Senator from Jackson, @Vice-President Noah (L-AR-JK), attempted to do this through executive action during his time as President. Unfortunately, he was stopped due to the law mandating that my Department continue to collect and store said records. While I cannot state the advice I gave as a result of that Executive Order last year during his term; I can say that how we got here today was done with the persistent and continued work of the Senator from Jackson standing up for the rights of gun owners, and of law-abiding American citizens.

In conclusion, I believe that *S.5* strikes the right balance between the individual right to bear arms and the need for public safety. It is an important step forward in the respect of individual privacy and the prevention of government overreach, and as such, I voice my support for its passage.

Thank you for your time and consideration.
ID: 1111031430017974302

I move to amend S.8 as follows:

The following be inserted as Section 3, after "Definitions", and the further sections be renumbered accordingly:
SEC. 3. REPEAL.
IN GENERAL‚Äî. The Constitutional Convention Procedure Act, H.R. 14 of the 159th Session, is hereby repealed in its entirety. Section 4 of the named act shall still be enforced for the convention that convened on April 8th, 2023

Deleted User
01:38 AM
My purpose today here is to speak briefly on S.8.

The applications submitted by the States for a convention must elucidate clear instructions on the procedural conduct of the convention. If such details are not specified by at least three-fourths of the States, the pertinent sections of this rule will be enacted and in full force. This process can appear to be overtly bureaucratic, and carries a risk of becoming unlawful due to potential mishandling or errors.
ID: 1112917948470923264

I caution this in Senators deliberations, look forward to how the Department of Justice or counsel to the convention may have to argue this.

I move to amend S.8 Section 4 adding "The States, in their applications for a convention, shall specify instructions on how the convention shall conduct business. Such instructions must be uniform in nature and agreed upon by the Governors of the several states. When not specified, or agreed upon, by two-thirds of the States, the appropriate portions of this section shall be in force."

02:40 AM
I make a correction to my motion to amend and replace it with a motion to amend S.8 AS AMENDED by striking Section 5(a) and replacing it with the following:
"The States, in their applications for a convention, shall specify instructions on how the convention shall conduct business. Such instructions must be uniform in nature and agreed upon by the Governors of the several states. When not specified, or agreed upon, by two-thirds of the States, the appropriate portions of this section shall be in force."

ID: 1119337412510879766
JMP
06:58 PM
Thank you, Mr. Chairman, and to the rest of this esteemed body for holding me in consideration for such an estimable position as that of a Supreme Court vacancy. I understand that this nomination holds much gravity for the course of the judiciary‚Äîand I am sure you have questions which you'd like to ask‚Äîso I'll be brief:

I want only to say that I believe myself highly qualified, both in direct experience and in technical knowledge of American law. I have had the immense honor of serving this country as the Attorney General of the United States; and outside of public service, I have served both in private practice and in academic positions. My main areas of expertise are in constitutional law, administrative litigation, and early American legal history‚Äîall of which compose an essential aspect of the Court's docket. If I may run the risk of being adulatory, I believe myself to be well-qualified for this post. And I hope you will come to the same conclusion in the course of your questioning. Thank you.
ID: 1119340244513337474
Speaker Brown (the hot one)
07:01 PM
The @Senate Judiciary Committee shall not be in strict order, committee members may ask questions at their leisure the hearing portion shall conclude tomorrow at 2:46pm unless moved otherwise.
ID: 1119340925353730078
Speaker Brown (the hot one)
07:02 PM
Mr. JMP, I just have a few questions I would like answered,

What mode of constitutional interpretation do you subscribe to?

Do you believe that gerrymandering is subject to judicial review?

How much should the court rely on severing? Should that be left to the legislature?

Do you support the concept of substantive due process?

Do you support the enforcement of the dormant commerce clause?

What is your view on compelled speech? Should it how used to rectify discrimination by businesses?

Should the Safe Harbor Doctrine apply to website hosting businesses?

What is your opinion on the Chevron Doctrine?

The Takings Clause of the 5th Amendment states, "just compensation" be paid if private property is taken for public use. What does public use mean to you? Accessible by the public, or simply benefiting the public, or something else.

What is the most important aspect of our Constitution?

If someone was not in this hearing and looked through it to decide their vote, what would you want them to take away from it?

Would you be able to decide a case that goes against your moral beliefs?
ID: 1119341184930824272
Deleted User
07:02 PM
What is your judicial philosophy, and how would you apply it to your decision-making on the Supreme Court?
ID: 1119341312479600680
Deleted User
07:02 PM
Can you provide examples of cases or legal issues that you believe were wrongly decided by the Supreme Court, and how you would have approached those cases differently?
ID: 1119341364069531748
Deleted User
07:03 PM
How do you balance individual rights and liberties with the needs of society in your decision-making?
ID: 1119341402980102245
Deleted User
07:03 PM
What is your view on the role of precedent and stare decisis in the Supreme Court's decision-making process? When, if ever, would you be willing to overturn a previous decision?
ID: 1119341440988893324
Deleted User
07:03 PM
How would you approach cases involving controversial social issues, such as abortion, affirmative action, or religious freedom?
ID: 1119341547993976922
Deleted User
07:04 PM
What is your perspective on the role of the Supreme Court in addressing emerging technologies and their impact on society?
ID: 1119341666919251988
JMP
08:59 PM
@Speaker Brown (the hot one)
Mr. JMP, I just have a few questions I would like answered, What mode of constitutional interpretat
1.) In broad strokes, I believe that the constitution should be interpreted according to the original meaning of an educated layperson at the time of ratification. In instances of uncertainty, I believe that deference should be accorded to the wishes of our legislature, which has a popular mandate that the judiciary lacks.

2.) In line with the precedent established by prior nominees to the bench, I will reserve answering the specifics of controversies which may come before the court in the future. That said, I am sympathetic to the argument of Justice Scalia in *Vieth v. Jubelirer*, where he raised concerns with finding a judicially manageable standard for resolving those issues. And moreover, the constitution provides a remedy for instances of gerrymandering via Article I, ¬ß4‚Äîseemingly leaving the issue to the legislative branch to remedy.

2.) I do not think that the court should engage in severing when Congress has not explicitly declared its desire through a severability clause. Laws are generally designed in a manner such that the effect of their operation would change drastically were a sub-unit of the law to be modified; and the court should not second-guess whether Congress would want the law to remain in effect with severed content. There are also Presentment Clause issues and the nature of Art. III remedies that make me question whether severability is a valid judicial remedy in the first place.

3.) Though stare decisis should be accorded respect and would be a consideration in my mind during any ruling where substantive due process is encountered, I am skeptical of that doctrine. There are many historical reasons to think that the Fourteenth Amendment does not embrace a restriction on States' police powers in the manner which it has been interpreted to by the courts. I refer you to the work of Ryan Williams, David Bernstein, and Matthew Franck, all of whom have raised well-considered doubts as to whether the framers of 14A intended the amendment to have such an effect.

4.) I believe that my views on this matter are closest to that of Justice Scalia's, who expressed doubt as to the propriety of dormant commerce in his dissent in *Wynne v. Maryland*. This is certainly a difficult issue, and there are many early sources ‚Äî like Chief Justice Marshall's dicta in several cases ‚Äî that could be read in support of a dormant commerce clause. But I am not so convinced. And at the very least, the way it has been operationalized in "balancing tests" like *Pike v. Bruce Church* has its own share of criticism for being difficult to apply in a fair and even-handed manner.

5.) I believe that compelled speech lies at the very crux of not only the guarantee of free speech, but also the freedom of association, and more fundamentally the freedom of conscience, which several of our Founding Fathers wrote on extensively. I cannot say how the doctrine of compelled speech should be applied to any particular set of facts due to want of judicial neutrality‚Äîbut I believe it is an extremely important protection that should not be swept aside lightly.

6.) I apologize, but would you mind clarifying what you mean?

7.) I am sympathetic to the view that Thomas W. Merrill took on the issue in his book, "The Chevron Doctrine." I believe that *Chevron* itself has been abused and misconstrued in lower courts to grant far higher levels of deference to administrative agencies than is reasonable. I believe agencies should only be given deference for interpretations that have long-standing weight, were issued under a rigorous administrative record of public debate and cross-examined evidence, and which fairly comply with the plain meaning of the rule. I do not think we should rubber-stamp agency interpretations of law that are ill-considered.

8.) I think that "the public use" should have a direct, tangible connection to either a public function or direct public access. I am skeptical of the view of "public use" taken by cases like *Kelo*.
ID: 1119370802165457037
JMP
09:00 PM
(cont'd)
ID: 1119370831882113154
JMP
09:06 PM
9.) The most important aspect of our constitution is the ingenious manner in which it prevented the consolidation of power into the hands of one individual. The Bill of Rights is no doubt one of the most venerable pieces of law all of our civilization's history, but it is only through the abatement of tyranny that those guarantees are made secure. Without the first six articles, the bill of rights are, as Madison put it, a mere "parchment barrier."

10.) I would hope they they take away that I have spent a great many years of my life studying this topic deeply, and contemplating our legal tradition such as to ensure that the guarantees of our forefathers remain viable for ourselves and for our descendants to come.

11.) Yes. I believe that the task of law is an office that goes beyond my personal moral reservations.
ID: 1119372360689127494
JMP
09:10 PM
@Deleted User
What is your judicial philosophy, and how would you apply it to your decision-making on the Supreme
I would refer you to my first answer to Senator Brown's questions, but I am happy to provide any necessary clarification.
ID: 1119373460330778714
Deleted User
09:12 PM
@JMP
I would refer you to my first answer to Senator Brown's questions, but I am happy to provide any nec
Could you define what an ‚Äúeducated layperson at the time of ratification‚Äù is
ID: 1119373938963791934
JMP
09:16 PM
@Deleted User
Can you provide examples of cases or legal issues that you believe were wrongly decided by the Supre
Absolutely. Allow me to give an example that is illustrative of how I approach statutory construction, since this hasn't yet been encountered in the hearing.

In the case of *Smith v. United States*, the court found that exchanging a gun for illegal drugs constituted 'using' a firearm for the purposes of the Armed Career Criminal Act's sentence-enhancement provisions. Though by a literal rendering of the verb "to use" this would be true, Justice Scalia‚Äîfamously a textualist‚Äîdissented from the majority. He stated, and I agree with him, that words should be interpreted *reasonably* in a manner suited to the *context* of a sentence. Just as "using an umbrella" does not mean to trade it for drugs, so too does "using a firearm" mean using it for its intended purpose, i.e., to discharge it. I bring up this example because I think that many have in their mind the idea that textualism must necessarily mean "literalism" and interpreting law in a draconian manner. But it does not.
ID: 1119374901581721631
JMP
09:16 PM
@Deleted User
Could you define what an ‚Äúeducated layperson at the time of ratification‚Äù is
I will gladly answer this when I have responded to the first set of questions you provided
üëç 1
ID: 1119375007743746179
JMP
09:21 PM
@Deleted User
How do you balance individual rights and liberties with the needs of society in your decision-making
This is, of course, one of the most fundamental issues that a judge must grapple with. And it is necessarily more in the nature of an art than an exact science. My personal view is that our liberties should be given the full force which our founding fathers intended them to be given, and that within the sphere of liberty there is no room for "prudential" concessions to be made. The founders were unequivocal‚Äîa constitutional right is an area where the government is *powerless* to act.

This being said, there will always be gray areas in the law, either because the historical record is obscure, or because there was a diversity of opinion among our early sources. In those cases I would not arrogate the power of the judiciary over the legislature, and I would assume that the body which lies closer to the will of the people is better-suited to weigh the trade-offs between the needs of our social good and the needs of individual liberty. In this sense, I advocate for judicial restraint when we are in uncharted waters.
ID: 1119376191036600412
JMP
09:22 PM
Though I will clarify that "uncharted waters" does not mean that the judiciary cannot apply old principles to novel facts and novel technology. More to that in a moment.
ID: 1119376519400267776
JMP
09:28 PM
@Deleted User
What is your view on the role of precedent and stare decisis in the Supreme Court's decision-making
I believe that Justice Scalia provided a perfectly workable standard of stare decisis in *Montejo v. Louisiana*. One should consider the following: Whether the precedent has proven unworkable, fractious, or necessarily confusing; the antiquity of the decision; the reliance interests at stake; and whether the decision was well-reasoned. However, I personally believe that "reliance interests" have often been interpreted far too broadly, and in the common-law tradition referred specifically to tangible property interests (like for instance if a prior decision had vested title in someone, and a new decision would threaten clouding said title).

Additionally, I would say that stare decisis should be granted more weight in statutory decisions, because Congress can amend statutes when they believe the courts have erred in a judgment.
ID: 1119377975914266634
Deleted User
09:28 PM
In the context of the First Amendment, the Supreme Court has addressed the vagueness doctrine in cases such as Papachristou v. City of Jacksonville (1972) and City of Chicago v. Morales (1999). How would you evaluate the constitutionality of laws that are challenged as being unconstitutionally vague, and how would you balance the government's interest in clarity and enforcement with the need to protect individuals from arbitrary enforcement and chilling effects on free speech?
ID: 1119378024194904104
JMP
09:31 PM
@Deleted User
How would you approach cases involving controversial social issues, such as abortion, affirmative ac
I do not believe that an issue's being controversial should *per se* affect how the court should rule, seeing as the judiciary was designed specifically to be *insulated* from popular sentiment. That being said, I do think that the contentiousness of an issue can highlight that it may be more appropriate for resolution by the political process, and hence is amenable to judicial restraint and deference. Ongoing contention can also highlight whether a prior decision is ripe for reconsideration, based on its lacking "reliance interests" that are otherwise prevalent in settled decisions.
ID: 1119378656314277978
JMP
09:34 PM
@Deleted User
What is your perspective on the role of the Supreme Court in addressing emerging technologies and th
I believe that Justice Scalia put it best when he said that judges should "project" the arc of technology through the use of analogy. For instance: Are sound trucks protected by the First Amendment? Well, of course the founders didn't have sound trucks. But what they did have are a common-law doctrine of public nuisance, the remedies for abatement, etc. We also have prior case law for time, place, and manner restrictions. So I think that the judiciary should try to reason via suitable analogy from new technology back into old technology, and apply the principles which were hammered out and settled in respect to those analogues.
ID: 1119379467794653195
JMP
09:38 PM
@Deleted User
Could you define what an ‚Äúeducated layperson at the time of ratification‚Äù is
I think that the best definition of an "educated layperson" is a person who has a basic background in the common law tradition, and access to a dictionary so as to look-up terms of art. I do not believe this to be an unreasonable "legal fiction," seeing as Blackstone's *Commentaries* were one of the best-selling publications in the early colonial period, and many Americans partook in spirited debate about what shape their burgeoning government should take. This is the audience to whom the framers were writing.
ID: 1119380597530443796
JMP
09:42 PM
@Deleted User
In the context of the First Amendment, the Supreme Court has addressed the vagueness doctrine in cas
I would essentially concur in the test used by *Morales*. If a person of ordinary intelligence cannot discern whether their conduct would be illegal, then it probably runs afoul of the guarantee of due process. There are additionally heightened considerations that should be accorded to fundamental liberties, such as when a vague regulation implicates protected speech, rather than conduct. Criminal proscriptions should also be scrutinized very carefully, due to the rule of lenity.
ID: 1119381595497959464
Deleted User
09:44 PM
The Ninth Amendment recognizes unenumerated rights retained by the people. How would you determine the scope and protect the unenumerated rights under your judicial framework? <@301477892339138560>
ID: 1119382101955977257
JMP
09:47 PM
@Deleted User
The Ninth Amendment recognizes unenumerated rights retained by the people. How would you determine t
I think that I would push back against the premise a little bit. My understanding of the Ninth Amendment is essentially that it was put in as an interpretive provision because of the Federalists' argument that a bill of rights is impliedly preempted by the enumerated nature of the federal government's power. Essentially, "putting in a bill of rights would imply that Congress could otherwise legislate on these subjects," so said the Federalists. This provision ensured that Art. I, ¬ß8 would still be read as *exhaustive*.
ID: 1119382742140977272
JMP
09:48 PM
And therefore I do not read it as being an independent repository of rights. It is simply careful draftsmanship, as it were
ID: 1119383039286464542
Lionheart
10:11 PM (edited)
(<@301477892339138560> )

1. Mr. JMP, do you hold a license to practice law in your home state of Olympia (did you take the bar in Olympia or not)? If not, then what qualifies you for a confirmation when you have not met this basic requirement yet?

2. You failed to appear for your hearing as a chief justice nominee in Olympia, resulting in the withdrawal of your nomination. How can we trust you to be diligent and reliable in your duties if you have shown such negligence and irresponsibility before? And how can we assess your fitness for the supreme court of the United States, if you were deemed unfit by your own state legislature?

3. I also would like to inquire about you sponsoring a constitutional amendment that would substantially regulate the practice of abortion and how it impacts your opinions on Roe.
ID: 1119388698652450816
JMP
11:03 PM
@Lionheart
(<@301477892339138560> ) 1. Mr. JMP, do you hold a license to practice law in your home state of Ol
1.) I am not currently a member of the bar in Olympia, by virtue of my not having needed to be since leaving public office. All bar admissions I have needed in the past have been granted *ex officio*. However, being a member of a bar is not an actual requirement of this office, and historically there have been several justices of distinguished service who did not even graduate law *school*; Robert Jackson is the last example. I hope that my experience and answers at this hearing betoken my qualification for this position better than Olympia bar membership.

2.) As was indicated in the correspondence of President LeMaire, dated 05/31, regarding my nomination to the Secretary of Commerce and Labor, I was dealing with some unexpected health issues that impeded my ability to participate in a hearing. This will not be a recurring issue, but I understand that this might engender reasonable doubts in your mind.

3.) It is true that, in my capacity as a politicial official and private citizen, I have proposed and co-signed legislation to modify the standing which Roe v. Wade holds as law of the land. But of course, the issue which a judge has to face is a matter of law and what is presently true‚Äînot what is political and one *wishes* were true. Numerous Justices in history have held a long string of political assignments that required supporting or opposing case law that was good standing at that time. One can only hope that a Justice is responsible enough to separate their normative commitments from those of law; and I believe that I can.
ID: 1119401940284096523

I am highly qualified for this position as I have been admitted to every bar except for the State of Jackson. @Deleted User
Thank you Mr Chairman, and the rest of the esteemed Senate Judiciary Committee for considering my no
Mr. Oliver Hershey, what legal dilemmas did you encounter as an attorney that challenged your moral convictions, and how did you resolve them?
ID: 1121478824962576424
Deleted User
04:42 PM
@Lionheart
Mr. Oliver Hershey, what legal dilemmas did you encounter as an attorney that challenged your moral
Thank you for the question Senator. I have faced a few in my work as an attorney, mainly conflict of interest. This has occurred a few times, when I had to represent a group of people or a person in a case where I had to recuse myself due to the conflict of interest. Mainly the way to solve the conflicts of interest are mainly to recuse yourself. Another one I have faced is helping people acess justice. Due to the rising cost of lawyers, when one appears in court, they often find themselves unable to pay and that is, in my opinion, a big problem. I have served as peoples attorneys more often than not, as a pro-bono lawyer, where I do not charge for my services. If I pass this committee and the Senate, I will continue to work to make sure that all people who are unable to afford a lawyer, will be matched with a free public defender, or a lawyer who, like me, works mostly pro-bono.
ID: 1121480276778954762
Speaker Brown (the hot one)
05:15 PM
Mr. Hersey,
If someone was not in this hearing and looked through it to decide their vote, what would you want them to take away from it?

Would you be able to decide a case that goes against your moral beliefs?

Do you believe Janus was correctly decided?

What should be the burden for overturning precedent? How much do you believe in stare decisis?

What level of scrutiny do you believe should be applied to gun rights?

Do you believe the court was correct to curtail the Sherbert test?

Are you in favor or against commandeering (relating to states and the federal government (not property))?

Do you believe the Lemon test is a good precedent or should it be done away with?

Should the Political Question Doctrine be re-evaluated?

If a court decision is to be overturned, should it be done so gradually or swiftly?
ID: 1121488605064478750
Deleted User
05:18 PM
@Speaker Brown (the hot one)
Mr. Hersey, If someone was not in this hearing and looked through it to decide their vote, what woul
To answer your first question Mr Brown, I would say it is a little premature for that, I will answer it once I answer the rest of your questions.

for your second question: In the even that I am presiding over a case against my moral beliefs, I would recuse myself from that case. I do not see it fit that I preside over a case in which I have a standing conflict of interest in. I want to make sure that ever person who, if passed, appears in my courtroom has a fair trial. If i find that I have a conflict of interest, I will recuse myself to ensure that the person still has a fair trial and will not be forced to abide by a ruling I wrote with a personal bias against.
ID: 1121489413499789333
Deleted User
05:23 PM
Mr Brown, my job as a judge, if passed, is the abide by the law and to follow precedent. I do believe it was decided correctly however. I agree that a person who is not a member of a union should not pay union fees. Free association is where the citizens of the United States are allowed to associate with others in pursuit of a wide variety of political, social, economic, educational, religious, and cultural ends. But in the case of Janus vs. AFSCEME, I find that the people who do not want to associate should not pay, since if they are forced to pay, they, the unions, are forcing an association between that person and that union, of which violates that correspondent right. So I do believe that Janus was correctly decided.
ID: 1121490727134842963
Deleted User
05:31 PM
In my opinion, when it comes to overturning precedent, I believe that there is a heavy burden placed upon the people who are trying to overturn the precedent. I believe that the burden required is to provide information, of which a large amount must point to the fact that if the precedent is overturned it will right a wrong made by the court. I find that cases of overturning precedent must be met with extreme scrutiny because I do not believe that if a group provides just a soup√ßon of evidence, that it should be grounds for overturning a decision; especially if it is a major decision.

In terms for me, for me I believe about 75-25 when it comes to stare decisis. Mainly due to the fact that some of the cases that have been decided are old and do not accommodate for modern circumstances. I will follow vertical stare decisis and horizontal stare decisis.

I believe strict scrutiny is required since they are a fundamental right. And as a fundamental right, I believe that all laws that pertain to gun rights must be looked at with strict scrutiny to ensure they don‚Äôt violate the constitution
ID: 1121493282820739154

@Speaker Brown (the hot one)
Mr. Hersey, If someone was not in this hearing and looked through it to decide their vote, what woul
No, I believe that the sherbert test should not have been curtailed. The test ensures that the government does not burden a person because of their religious beliefs. And the test for the sherbert test was appropriate. I do not agree with the smith test, but I will abide by it according to stare decisis
ID: 1121494510397046926
Deleted User
05:44 PM
@Speaker Brown (the hot one)
Mr. Hersey, If someone was not in this hearing and looked through it to decide their vote, what woul
Due to the construction of our government and it‚Äôs basis in federalism. I believe that there is a case to argue for both sides. I, however, find that commandeering is well delegated in court and that more cases side with not supporting commandeering and finding commandeering unconstitutional. I do agree with the cases not supporting commandeering, mainly: Murphy vs. NCAA, and New York vs. The United States(1992)

With the lemon test we protect the barrier between church and state while also protecting the freedom of religion. But I do support a reworking of the test to make it less vague.

Deleted User
05:55 PM
@Speaker Brown (the hot one)
Mr. Hersey, If someone was not in this hearing and looked through it to decide their vote, what woul
I have reasons to agree with both gradually and swiftly. It depends on what the contents of the decision are because there are some cases, that if overturned and that overturning is done swiftly, it could cause chaos. It is a more subjective and more case by case situation since the overturning of a case varies by the decision. One could be about the death penalty and one, for example, is Brown vs. Board of education. The death penalty case, if overturned, should be swiftly implemented to ensure nobody else is killed via the death penalty when it was overturned in the courts. But in the case of Brown vs. Board of education, I find that a gradual approach is required. In Brown v Board, if the students were immediately entered into the school and not gradually, it would impact the safety of those students, a gradual approach, as was done by the government, helped ensure the safety of the students and smooth transition, that was less likely to hurt people.
ID: 1121498618432594001
Deleted User
05:55 PM
I would like to reiterate I find that it is a case by case basis.

pigna_alex
04:58 PM
Thank you, sir. I extend my gratitude, esteemed members of this committee, for granting me with your precious time and profound consideration. During this hearing, I will be expressing my commitment towards assuming the mantle of the judicial circuit office with solemnity and respect. I pledge to administer justice in strict accordance with the Constitution of the United States of America, guided solely by impartiality and loyalty to the nation.

We find ourselves fortunate to live in a nation rich with bountiful harvests reaped from a Constitutional-Republican form of government that is built on *We The People*. But, we must not forget that such blessings can swiftly destruct, should they fall into the clutches of wrong hands. I hope that the Senate deems me worthy to bear such a duty and maintain our blessings, because I stand ready to embrace the magnitude of its gravity.

pigna_alex
05:22 PM
@Speaker Brown (the hot one)
Mr. Long, What is your stance on Roe v. Wade? What is your stance on the 2nd Amendment? Do you bel
From its very conception in 1973, the *Roe v. Wade* decision has been tainted by fallacy, its underpinnings demonstrate zero solid constitutional basis. The ramifications stemming from this ill-conceived ruling have been detrimental, casting a long shadow over our legal system and furthering the cause of judicial activism. While I recognize as a District Judge I will be forced ministerially to uphold SCOTUS precedent, I am of the belief that we should restore the matter of abortion to the purview of our elected representatives, whose voices echo the will of the people.

Plainly, *Roe* jurisprudence is quite literally a figment of legal imagination and an embodiment of judicial activism run amok. To read the majority opinion requires mental gymnastics.
ID: 1121852861454749746

Mr. Long, What is your stance on Roe v. Wade? What is your stance on the 2nd Amendment? Do you bel
I, like the Founders, understand that the right to keep and bear arms serves as a fundamental check against tyrannical government, and a guarantee of self defense. It is a core and essential protection in the Bill of Rights and must not be infringed. As a Judge, I will align myself with Justice Story's legal philosophy in *Commentaries on the Constitution of the United States * ‚ÄúThe militia is the natural defence of a free country against sudden foreign invasions, domestic insurrections, and domestic usurpations of power by rulers. It is against sound policy for a free people to keep up large military establishments and standing armies in time of peace, both from the enormous expenses, with which they are attended, and the facile means, which they afford to ambitious and unprincipled rulers, to subvert the government, or trample upon the rights of the people‚Ä¶‚Äù

ID: 1121861287589199982
Speaker Brown (the hot one)
05:56 PM
What do you think about the Lemon test and is a good precedent or should it be done away with?
ID: 1121861410549415987
pigna_alex
06:09 PM
@Speaker Brown (the hot one)
What do you think about the Lemon test and is a good precedent or should it be done away with?
The Lemon test, with its prongs dictating that a religious display must have a secular purpose and neither advance religion, is an egregious test that renders it susceptible to exploitation. Its expansiveness permits nearly any manifestation, no matter how tangentially connected, to be construed as "advancing religion". The repercussions of such a broad interpretation are widespread, particularly for financially stressed local governments, who find themselves entangled in potential litigation perhaps even by recognizing Christmas. This robs Americans of rich centuries-old tradition of religion in civic life, of which was recognized by President Washington when he stated "Of all the dispositions and habits, which lead to political prosperity, Religion and Morality are indispensable supports. In vain would that man claim the tribute of Patriotism, who should labor to subvert these great pillars of human happiness, these firmest props of the duties of Men and Citizens. The mere Politician, equally with the pious man, ought to respect and to cherish them. A volume could not trace all their connexions with private and public felicity. Let it simply be asked, Where is the security for property, for reputation, for life, if the sense of religious obligation desert the oaths, which are the instruments of investigation in Courts of Justice?"

The test, in my opinion, should only prohibit the advancement of religion where there is a coercive mechanism to *adhere* to whatever religion the government is allegedly advancing. This allows the Founders‚Äô desire for a moral citizenry informed by religious history to flourish while also banning direct unconstitutional religious coercion.
ID: 1121864503458529430
pigna_alex
06:09 PM
The Lemon test is so broad and wide that it allows almost *any* religious display to be banned contrary to the intention of the Founders and tradition.
ID: 1121864630789226636
pigna_alex
06:14 PM
@Deleted User
Do you believe that the M'Naughten test should be removed or reformed? Do you agree with the Mille
I would say that the M'Naughten test is a suitable examination for determining insanity, and from my understanding a commonly used one.
ID: 1121865801167798293
pigna_alex
06:19 PM
@Deleted User
Do you believe that the M'Naughten test should be removed or reformed? Do you agree with the Mille
I find that the Miller test is a fair mechanism for determining obscenity of speech or expression, although it should be reformed for jurisdiction in the internet age.
ID: 1121867065305866361
pigna_alex
06:24 PM
@Deleted User
Do you believe that the M'Naughten test should be removed or reformed? Do you agree with the Mille
The Supreme Court has ruled that generally the death penalty does not violate the Eighth Amendment's ban on cruel and unusual punishment, which I must uphold. This is only applicable if the death penalty results in a proportionate application, or if the penalty is proportional to the crime committed, such as murder.
ID: 1121868363551998123
pigna_alex
06:33 PM
@Deleted User
Do you believe that the M'Naughten test should be removed or reformed? Do you agree with the Mille
I believe that the Constitution should be interpreted in its original meaning when it was ratified and spearheaded by the Founding Fathers.
ID: 1121870692523200612
pigna_alex
06:42 PM (edited)
@Deleted User
Do you believe that the M'Naughten test should be removed or reformed? Do you agree with the Mille
The Courts of the United States should never follow demonstrably erroneous precedent. If the Court encounters a decision that is not a permissible interpretation of the text, the error should be swiftly corrected. A demonstrably erroneous judicial decision, is essentially making law, and adhering to it both tramples on the Constitution and perpetuates a usurpation of the legislative power.
ID: 1121872856997961809
pigna_alex
06:45 PM
That is if such a court has the ability to do that*

While I hold views in my capacity as a citizen, my rulings will be rooted in strict recognition of the Constitution of the United States of America and its statutory texts, provided that the latter doesn't violate the former.

ID: 1121886042170064906
pigna_alex
09:24 PM
@Deleted User
Are you barred in any of the states you will have to represent ? Have you argued any cases?
It is noteworthy to mention that famous Chief Justices throughout history, John Marshall, Roger Taney, Charles Evans Hughes, and Earl Warren were confirmed without any prior judicial experience during their confirmation. Remarkably, a staggering 41 justices in total have ascended to the highest level of the judiciary without judicial experience per se.

In light of this, I present my own qualifications. From the years 2006 to 2007, I was entrusted with the role of a mediator under the Georgia Office of Dispute Resolution, resolving society's conflicts with impartiality. Furthermore, my tenure as a paralegal has afforded me the opportunity to diligently compose competent contracts. These experiences have furthered my ability to exercise impartiality and fair judgment.

Turning to my academic record, I am proud to call myself an alumni at the Vanderbilt University School of Law. There, I pursued my Juris Doctor degree.

It is through this legal education and knowledge that I stand before this committee, fully prepared to take on the duty of upholding justice, liberty, and the Constitution of the United States of America.

idkbroidk
12:14 AM
My name is Megan Whitaker, and I would like to thank this Committee for giving me the opportunity to be here today. I‚Äôd like to start by giving you some background about myself. I hold a bachelor‚Äôs degree from Dartmouth University, where I studied political science and economics with a minor in military history. After graduating, I had the distinct honor of serving for 12 years in the United States Navy. After leaving the military, I studied law at Georgetown University, where I graduated summa cum laude. I subsequently clerked for the Honorable Frank Easterbrook, chief judge of the Seventh Circuit, and interned at both the Permanent Court of Arbitration and the Inter-American Court of Human Rights. I subsequently worked as an AUSA in the civil division of the US Attorney‚Äôs Office for the Southern District of New York. Prior to being nominated for this position, I was a partner at White & Case LLP, where I worked on a variety of cases involving transactional law and litigation. I primarily focused on international business law.

Speaker Brown (the hot one)

@idkbroidk
In my opinion, it is amusing and serves as an excellent case study for civil procedures classes.

ID: 1123774470767783947
idkbroidk
12:42 AM
The Plaintiff sought to file an in forms pauperis action against Satan under Title 42, Section 1983 of the US Code. The decision in the case discussed the jurisdictional issues with suing Satan, enumerated and discussed the requirements for a class action suit, and ultimately ruled that Mayo had not properly served the Defendant with the suit.
